DNA Sequencing Results (posted 18-Jun-19):
> An clean and well-resolved nrDNA sequence of 1661 bps was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this collection. It consists of a reverse read that gave an almost complete nrITS sequence of 682 bps (the first 60 characters of ITS1 region are missing), followed by a the first 979 bps of nrLSU (through to and including the LR5 primer); the LSU trace is a two-read consensus sequence. There are no ambiguous characters present.
> A BLASTn of the ITS sequence gave the following high-value hits:
KY826004: “Boletales sp. voucher B0681” from Canada ==> 682/682 = 100% match
KY825963: “Boletales sp. voucher B0091” from Canada ==> 682/682 = 100% match
KM248936: “Boletus subglabripes isolate 3660” from Canada ==> 682/682 = 100% match
> A BLASTn of the first 962 bps of the LSU sequence gave the following high-value hits:
EU522757: “Xerocomus cf. impolitus TM02_243” from southern Ontario, Canada ==> 857/858 = 99.88% similar
KF030303: “Boletus subglabripes voucher 72206” from New Hampshire ==> 870/872 = 99.77% similar (1 ambiguity and a G/C mismatch)
results.location_name: Berkshire Hills Eisenberg Camp, Copake, New York, USA

results.notes: In lawn near rotting Tilia stump. Growing in small clumps. Caps convex to flat with wavy margin, medium brown maturing to yellowish brown, 5-10 cm, covered with hairs that are golden near the cap edges and darken near the center of the cap. Gills white to cream, attached to subdecurrent, white cortina collapses to a yellowish ephemeral annulus. Stipe 10-15 mm thick at apex, widening toward the slightly swollen base, which stains yellow. Stipe pale brown covered with whitish fibrils. Base attached to black rhizomorph which is round in x.s.

results.notes: Growing from a rotting birch log. Caps bright yellow to yellowish orange, very slimy. Younger caps covered with brownish scales that tend to disappear as the caps mature. results.notes:
General Notes (last updated 29-Jan-19):
> This collection was made by Diane Alden at the COMA Foray (Walk #7). Diane brought this bolete to my attention while we were in the woods. She found it in a hemlock-dominant forest.
> The unusual shape & stunted growth are probably due in part to persistently dry conditions preceding the foray. The pores surface appears to be white. There was NO bluing anywhere in the fruitbody.
> No one at the foray could ID this critter even to the genus. It was logged as “Boletaceae” prior to my receipt of the sequencing results.
> The series of photos were taken at slightly different lighting conditions inside a dwelling (e.g., near a window with natural light, or a mix of natural and artificial light, etc.). Pertinent metadata included in the pic captions.
> This collection was also posted by John Plischke as obs 262705.

DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (posted 29-Jan-19):
Results:
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 1606 bps was obtained from this material by Dr. Kudzma. It consists of the last 625 characters of nrITS (partial ITS1, complete 5.8S and ITS2 regions), followed by the first 981 bps of the nrLSU locus (through to and including the LR5 primer). There are no ambiguous characters present in the entire sequence.
> A BLASTn of the 859 bps fragment of the nrLSU locus (the region between the ITS6R and LR5 primers) firmly places this species in the subfamily Xerocomoideae, and the hit profile suggests Aureboletus. There are no perfect matches, however, and the top hit, “Aureoboletus roxanae voucher DS626-07” (KF030311), is only 99.2% similar (834/841).1
A cladogram consisting of 30 carefully chosen BLASTn hits representing several genera housed in Xerocomoideae was built in GenBank, annotated and posted to this observation.
> A BLASTn of the ITS sequence was also carried out. It, too, suggests likely placement of this collection in Xerocomoideae, though this locus is not used for making inter-generic phylogenetic inferences. The top hits are “Aureoboletus sp. voucher JLF 6331” (MH213057, 627/630 = 99.5%) and “Boletales sp. voucher RL039” (KY826191, 640/649 = 98.6%).
Apparently, there are very few ITS sequences of Aureboletus in GenBank, as per the results of this BLASTn. A cladogram consisting of only 8 relevant hits was built in GenBank, annotated and posted to this observation.
Discussion:
> Assembly of a LSU tree with the meaningful topology needed quite a bit of work. The greatest challenge had to do with the proper choice of hits that would provide the requisite monophyly for all selected genera, particularly Aureoboletus itself. This difficulty demonstrates the known deficiency of LSU for building reliable single-locus inter-generic phylogenies. Other than that, GenBank software quirks and voucher identification issues may have exacerbated the problem. For example, inclusion of “non-core” Aureboletus taxa, such as mirabilis and projectellus, as well as of some exotic taxa with lower % similarity, severely distorted the topology and made Aureoboletus polyphyletic. In the end it all worked out, and an approximate monophyly of Aureboletus was achieved. Importantly, however, the clustering of catenarius, moravicus, roxanae and yunnanensis as a subclade in Aureboletus mirrors the results seen in the multi-locus analysis of Wu et al. (2016).2
> The ITS tree maps only a handful of trusted accessions of Aureoboletus available in GenBank. If one disregards the two “K” ambiguities in “voucher JLF6331”, it is conspecific with MO294173. Identification of “Boletales sp. RL039” as Aureboletus roxanae was made possible by Renée Lebeuf with a kindly supplied photograph of her collection (posted herein). This means that another voucher of J.L. Frank’s, #6330, is also A. roxanae. However, since the observed pairwise genetic distance between MO294173 & Renée Lebeuf’s A. roxanae is 1.4%, the two are likely not contaxic. On the other hand, ITS sequencing of additional collections of A. roxanae would be required to probe the natural range of intra-specific variability for this species.
Conclusion: Though field identification of MO294173 even to the genus was not possible, phylogenetically this bolete clades in Aureboletus. The closest relative appears to be A. roxanae, as the pairwise genetic distances of 0.8% and 1.4% for nrLSU and nrITS, respectively, suggest the two taxa are not conspecific. Sequencing of additional loci would probably resolve any lingering doubts regarding the identity of this collection relative to A. roxanae.
References:
1 To date, “voucher DS626-07” happens to be the only collection identified as A. roxanae that has been sequenced for 3 phylogenetically relevant loci (nrLSU, TEF-1 and RPB-1), with the data posted to GenBank. These sequences have been used in several molecular studies of Bolecaeae since 2013.
2 Wu et al., “One hundred noteworthy boletes from China”, Fungal Diversity 2016, term 81, p. 30.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_1093/2017_DSC9358

Habitat: Mixed wood, Fagus sylvatica dominant, Picea abies scattered; slightly inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; calcareous, colluvial, shallow ground; relatively warm and dry place; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 6-9 deg C, elevation 670 m (2.200 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: forest soil, leaf litter.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, right bank of river Soča; between villages Soča and Trenta; near the trail to settlement Na skalah, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Index Fungorum recognizes Cortinarius allutus as a current name, while other authorities consider it as a synonym of Cortinarius multiformis (this too is a current name according to IF). Recent (2014) DNA phylogenetic studies (Ref.8) revealed that much more complex situation exists in the group of species similar to this find. Ref.8 considers now the name Cortinarius allutus as a misapplied name. Anyway, I will keep with Index Fungorum and use the name Cortinarius allutus. Macroscopic traits and spores fit well to the most of the descriptions found in literature.

There grew 6 or 7 pilei in an area of about 3 × 3 m. Habitat was montane Fagus sylvatica forest with a few Picea abies intermixed. In a distance of 0.3 – 3 m from the pilei two young, about 1-1.5 m tall and in a distance of about 5 m a grown up Picea abies three were present. Cortinarius allutus is supposed to be in mycorrhizal relation to conifers. Fruitbody description: pilei diameter 6 – 9 cm, trama thin near the edge of pilei, in the midrange about 8 mm thick, gills up to 10 mm broad, hut dry (after a several days long dry period); however, leaves and other debris were firmly ‘glued’ to the hut surface (ixocutis); stipe 4.2 – 6.5 cm long and 8 – 20 mm in diameter; when old stipe partly hollow; quite abruptly bulbous (with a few fruitbodies almost marginate); bulb from 1.6 to 1.9 times the diameter of the stipe; smell mild, pleasant, mushroomy, on leather?; taste not tested; 5% KOH reactions: on trama yellow-brown, not violent; on hut brownish, deepens the color of the hut; trama in the bulb brownish; on gills dark brown, almost blackish; Lugol reactions: on trama instant gold-yellowish, on pilei slightly yellowish, almost none; pilei do not bruise when handled except gills – they darken slightly; SP abundant, almost the same color as the whole fruitbodies, buff-fox color, oac714.

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Sony ILCE6000 / Carl Zeiss Vario-Tessar E 16-70mm/ f4

results.notes:
Habitat: found in sandy woodland soil along a seasonally wet swale. Mixed woods including eastern white pine, tulip poplar, and a variety of other mature deciduous species

Cap: diameter 9.8 cm, dry, broadly convex, streaky grayish-brown darkest over the disc, margin weakly striate (12 mm), not appendiculate. Warts, soft and chunky, brown to gray-brown. Flesh white, not staining

Gills: white, not particularly close, just free with a small tooth on the stipe, some forking near stipe, lamellulae of various lengths are abruptly attenuate, gill edges minutely fringed and gray marginate

Stipe: length 14 cm, apex diameter 11 mm, expanding to 18 mm at base, powdery pale gray at apex, gray fibrils lower down arranged in irregular chevrons, stalk is stuffed with white pith (cortex 5 mm thick). Exannulate. Base not bulbed, covered by a thick and partially free layer of universal veil material that is clay brown to gray. Flesh white except reddish brown at base, not staining

Odor: none

Spores: white, subglobose to globose 8-10 × 7.5-9.5 μm

results.notes:
This photo was sent to me by a contact through the Bolete Filter. I am told that it was found at sea level among mixed conifers, including Douglas Fir in particular. The sender suspects it is conifericola and that is the sole basis for the suggested name.

I know nothing more about it. I have sent the following request but do not know if anything will come back.

“Any bitter taste? Any bluing of the flesh when it was cut? Any other photos at all? It would help a lot to see even a specimen cut in half, or a closeup display of the junction between stem and pores. I will go ahead and post this single photo but I suspect that those will be immediate and important questions.”

The response was this: “Blueing when cut then eventually turning back to original color. Didn’t really taste bitter but did not taste a large piece.”

results.notes:
Abundant under Alnus incana in the “Asbury fen”. Caps smooth. Fruiting bodies shriveled up before I could take further pictures. Pleurocystidia absent. Cheilocystidia urticoid and hyaline, some with slight apical knobs. Cheilocystidia measurements: (27.7) 28.7 – 44.6 (45.1) × (6.4) 6.9 – 9.9 (10.3) µm; Q = (3.3) 3.5 – 5.5 (6); N = 10; Me = 35.6 × 8.2 µm; Qe = 4.4. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores brown, thick-walled and verrucose. Spore measurements: (7.7) 8.4 – 10.3 (11.3) × 5 – 5.7 (6) µm; Q = (1.5) 1.6 – 1.9 (2); N = 30; Me = 9.3 × 5.4 µm; Qe = 1.7.

results.notes:
A single fruitbody found by an unknown NJMA foray participant. No habitat details, but my guess it was probably growing with Betula.
Rancocas S.P. is on the fringe of the Pine Barrens, with a mostly mixed deciduous habitat, especially to the north of the creek. While birch is not common in this part of the state, Betula is scattered throughout the NJ Pine Barrens as isolated trees or small stands.
Mophologically, this scaber stalk looked very similar, if not identical, to my other observations of this scabrum-like taxon or taxa from NJ:obs 281644, obs 287648, obs 288622 and obs 288623; however, the exposed context of this collection stained brownish-red throughout the fruitbody and no bluing was observed anywhere. In this regard, it’s identical to -623, while the other 3 aforementioned collections stained only blue, and the color was restricted to the lower half of stipe.
results.location_name: Rancocas State Park, Burlington Co., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
Found in an open area midway between a live oak and a big pine. I’ve seen this taxon growing in association with magnolia and (mistakenly, I think) identifies it as Boletus vermiculosus. The younger material has a rich dark red pore surface which lightens apparently with age. Pore surface and stipe stain dark blue-black quickly. Context also stains quickly, but with a lighter blue. The stipe has a pattern of regularly-spaced black specks, making it almost seem checkered. Sterile margin on caps. Taste and odor are mild.

results.notes:
A NJMA Foray collection. A single perfect specimen collected by me in the immediate vicinity of white and chestnut oaks in pine-oak barrens. It was growing in sandy soil on the edge of a trail in woods, about 50 yards from Don Connor Boulevard.

The following measurements were taken a few hours post collection:
Cap = 5.3 cm in diameter and 0.5 cm thick in the middle.
Gills = 6 mm wide max.
Stipe = totally elongate and sub-clavate, 8 cm long (excluding the thickness of volval sack), 8 mm wide at apex and 1.4 cm wide near the base; the central cylinder is 2-3 mm wide in the apex and 7 mm wide in the base.
Volval sack = 2.2 to 3.2 cm tall and 1.8 cm wide; sack wall is up to 2.5 mm thick; a limbus internus was not visualized.

A spore deposit was obtained; spore measurements to be posted later.
The material was preserved and is available for study/research (50/50 split with RET).
results.location_name: Forest Resource Education Center, Jackson Twp., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
I suspect these are the same sp. as http://mushroomobserver.org/291061?q=A4jE which keyed out to P. cyanopus using http://openjournals.wsu.edu/...
I noticed the habitat for cyanopus is described as the roots and humus under big trees like Quercus (abundant in my area). So while out hiking looking for mushrooms this morning I took the time to search out spots that match this description, and sure enough there they were! Fruiting from the debris and mossy bark at the base of 2 large oaks just as described. Im trying to be skeptical of this ID but the (so far) perfect match to P. cyanopus is to strong to propose anything better.

European P. cyanopus might be different from our NA collections but they seem to fit the description perfectly. As far as I can tell P. cyanopus is still an accepted name for NA collections so I dont know what else to call these.

results.notes:
Taste slowly peppery acrid. I wouldn’t necessarily say very acrid, but not something I would be interested in eating.
Flesh white and chalky textured, becoming pale tan. Creamy off white to white on pileus at collection, with weekly tinted and wrinkly margin, slowly got a pale buff wash, but essentially stayed of white for months. Specimen was very smooth and dry. Lamellar margins darker and toastier in color than the inner edge wash.
Stipe was swollen toward the base as shown, and remained white, with a few vague pale brown spots when aged.
This was covered in very fine dirt. It was in a group of mixed conifers, several pines and a few true firs and Douglas firs. I will see if I wrote down the tree these were closest to.

results.notes:
> A single young/immature fruitbody found at the NJMA foray by K. Itagaki and M. Michleski. The habitat is a wetland area near a stream or pond (now fairly dry due to the weather conditions in the last 4-6 weeks). There is no question about this being a species from sect. Scabra, whose members are strictly associated with birch tree. The ecology around FREC is the typical NJ Pine Barrens habitat with scrub oak and pitch pine; isolated small clusters of birch trees are known to be scattered throughout the NJ Pinelands.
> A finely rimose tan/light brown cap, whole cap margin, and a dense coating of dark gray to blackish scabers. When sectioned, the context was originally white, except the yellow area in the tip of base. The reddish discoloration took a couple of minutes to develop, reaching full intensity around 10 min post sectioning. Note the small blue areas in the base of stipe.
> I don’t think this is L. holopus on account of the dark cap, prominent staining and the geography (south and east of the reported range).
> Compare with obs 294492 that was collected 4 weeks before and 30 miles to the southwest of FREC.
DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (posted 29-May-21):
> A clean and contiguous full-length nrDNA sequence of 1015 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and posted by me to this observation. The full-length nrITS locus is 930 bps long in this organism/species (ITS1 = 468 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps, ITS2 = 301 bps). The ITS sequence is preceded by the last 23 characters of nrSSU and is followed by the first 62 nucleotides of nrLSU. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype.
The sequence is a partial consensus of one forward and one reverse read that share a 776-character common overlap in ITS. A full-length consensus sequence is impossible to derive in cases like this, considering how long the ITS locus is and the fact that no read can be 100% legible for such a duration due to the natural deterioration (broadening) of peak shapes.
> A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS returned 7 accessions having 98.4-99.9% similarity to the query. Only two of these, KM248967 and KM248968, have been identified to species, albeit incorrectly in both cases. Their alignment with the ITS of MO294653 is shown in Fig. 1. There is no question we are dealing with the same North American species here, as the observed mismatching positions are scattered single-base ambiguities and gaps due to variable-length homopolymers or possibly editing errors.
Curiously, all seven accessions are from Canadian vouchers, but this species obviously has to be be widely distributed in the northeast, considering it was found in NJ.
> As to the ID, I don’t how to call the present collection even though the species it represents may have been described by a mycologist of the past, e.g., A.H. Smith, who erected many epithets for scaber-stalks in his famous The Boletes of Michigan. It follows from the ITS sequence and known published data (the pioneering work of den Bakker & Noordeloos) that this entity is clearly not any of the European taxa, like L. holopus, or L. scabrum or L. variicolor, that do occur in North America. Nor is it L. snellii because the ITS2 sequence of the Smith’s type collection, AY853545, is very different. That said, the aforementioned KM248967 and KM248968 have been misidentified.

The flesh was already dingy yellowish when the fruitbody was sectioned. Just like in 294653, the context in cap and upper stipe gradually stained red and the bluing was restricted to the lower stipe.

results.notes:
A single specimen collected by a NJMA participant at the group foray. We saw many, many examples of Amanita lavendula, which was the most abundant mushroom at the ID tables, and is a very easy species to identify. This particular mushroom doesn’t look like a typical lavendula, but what else can it be?

Description: The oval-shaped, planar cap with rounded, short-striate edge is 5.0 × 4.5 cm wide and 0.5 cm thick in the middle; the surface is slightly tacky when wet and shiny when dry, subtly virgate, whitish with pale steely-violet hues (especially over the disk) and erratic yellowish-brown splashes/stains here and there. The gills are crowded and 0.3 cm wide; lamellulae are plentiful, of various lengths and are sub-truncate to rounded-attenuate. The annulate stipe is whitish above the ring and stained grayish-brown below (probably due to handling), 8.5 cm long, 0.8 cm wide at apex, uniformly 0.6 cm thick below and all the way down to the somewhat squishy, subglobose bulb, which is 1.3 cm long and 1.1 cm wide and with a short, sub-abrupt edge. The fuscous annulus is membranous, thin, collapsed and tightly appressed to the stipe, and is attached midway between the apex and the bulb (3 cm below cap-stipe juncture). The volva is present as whitish to grayish, thin and appressed-felty patches near the cap margin and as a grayish-lavender appressed collar-like band on the bulb shoulder. The flesh is white and solid, both in the cap and stipe, not staining. The odor is nill. The flesh was not tasted. The spores appear globose to subglobose at x400 (measurements to be made and posted later).

results.notes:
Habitat/Location: Top of forest ridge, growing in thick mulch/leaves below large hardwoods. In dense, mixed hardwood (spotted with pines) forest in Northwest Georgia, US.

Gills: Aged, blush to cream. Appear crowded.

Stipe: Blush to Cream, slightly mottled texture. Flesh beneath is brown. Small annulus present towards top.

Cap: Dark blush to cream. Dry. Somewhat depressed in Center. Remnants of veil/warts present.

Spore print color: None.

Bruising: No major bruising noticeable.

results.location_name: Peoples State Forest, Barkhamsted, Connecticut, USA

results.notes: Large, bulbous fungi growing in a cluster of two. Each has a spongy (slimy) gray/brown/green mass surrounded by a blush/cream/brown crust-like peridium (looks sort of like cracked sourdough bread). One appears to be splitting open to form “arms,” typical of earth stars. Each one of these is larger than my fist. They were found at the top of ridge near pine/mixed hardwood forest in Northeast Alabama (Cherokee County). They were growing in a compost pile (with a lot of campfire ash), pine needles, etc. Any help with an ID is much appreciated!
results.location_name: Collinsville, Alabama, USA

results.notes:
Habitat/Location: Open field in Northeast Alabama (Cherokee County) surrounded by pine/mixed hardwood forest. Quite a distance to the nearest trees. Closest trees include persimmon, sweet gum, maple, birch, and sycamore.

Fertile surface: Pale golden (buttery) pores, circular to elliptical. Younger specimens have fertile surface covered in a slippery cream-colored veil.

Stipe: Cream, covered in red to brown glandular dots (from top to bottom). Remnants of veil.

Cap: Golden brown, slightly slippery/moist

Spore print color: Brown

Bruising: No major bruising noticeable upon cutting. Some dark spots on pores around the stipe on some of the older mushrooms.
results.location_name: Collinsville, Alabama, USA

results.notes:
Habitat/Location: Top of forest ridge, growing in thick mulch/leaves below large hardwoods and pines. In Northeast Alabama (Cherokee County), US.

Gills: White to cream, crowded, covered in a white veil

Stipe: White, slightly scaled appearance, ending in large, ridged basal volva

Cap: White, waxy texture, white warts around the edge.

Spore print color: White

Bruising: No major bruising noticeable.
